body: Could you say a little more about how you executed native-image (e.g. command line parameters, if you profiled the application first etc)?

issue.title: Add sympy=1.1.1 to Linux docker image

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
**Description**:
Add sympy=1.1.1 to Linux docker image
**Motivation and Context**

- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve?
For #5162 
- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here.

body:
Absolutely (let me preface by saying this is my first time using Quarkus or native images in general):

Based on profiling, I added the following to `application.properties`:
```
quarkus.native.additional-build-args =\
-H:ResourceConfigurationFiles=resources-config.json, \
-H:ReflectionConfigurationFiles=reflection-config.json
```
Which contain:
```
{
  "resources": [
    {"pattern":"\\Qai/onnxruntime/native/linux-x64/libonnxruntime.so\\E"},
    {"pattern":"\\Qai/onnxruntime/native/linux-x64/libonnxruntime4j_jni.so\\E"}
  ]
}
```

and
```
[
  {
    "name" : "ai.onnxruntime.OrtEnvironment",
    "allDeclaredConstructors" : true,
    "allPublicConstructors" : true,
    "allDeclaredMethods" : true,
    "allPublicMethods" : true,
    "allDeclaredFields" : true,
    "allPublicFields" : true
  }
]
```

I also added libgomp to the Dockerfile
```
RUN microdnf -y install libgomp \
    && microdnf update \
    && microdnf clean all
```

On the command line, I use
```
./gradlew clean build -Dquarkus.package.type=native -Dquarkus.native.container-build=true && \
 docker build -f src/main/docker/Dockerfile.native -t quarkus/test-service . && \
 docker run --name onnx -it --rm -p 8080:8080 quarkus/test-service
```

I've tried adding the libraries onto the image, I've tried starting the application with 
```
./application -Donnxruntime.native.onnxruntime.path=/usr/lib64/libonnxruntime.so -Donnxruntime.native.onnxruntime4j_jni.path=/usr/lib64/libonnxruntime4j_jni.so
```
I've tried skipping and not skipping the loading of the library. Not sure what the right combination is.
This is great, thank you so much! Let me check it locally and see if I can fix it on Quarkus

@Craigacp I finally got around to trying to replicate your example and that works on my local machine. Have you been able to try and create a new Java project with ONNX as a dependency and have that work with native builds? I am still seeing the same issues when building my project using my local graal environment, not using the quarkus wrapper

I've not tried it in another project, but I'd be surprised if it didn't work given the modular nature of it. Does your jni-config.json look like it's got the right bits in? And is the agent still being run to generate all the config files?
I just tried to do this with a very basic project that depends on the runtime and it works, so it must be something with how Quarkus does the packaging. Thank you for helping me track this down!

@OmriShiv I see this issue is resolved. I have some experience with building native-images from jars including those that have external linking that can be tricky. And I put together this [shell-script to build native image from jar files](https://github.com/neomatrix369/awesome-ai-ml-dl/blob/master/examples/tribuo/builder.sh), also see the usage illustrations in the [README](https://github.com/neomatrix369/awesome-ai-ml-dl/tree/master/examples/tribuo#native-image-build-optional). In case you are trying to build artifacts outside the Quarkus world this might help.

Any feedback or contributions are welcome.
@neomatrix369 Thank you. I actually did manage to get this to work outside of Quarkus; but have still not been able to get it to work with Quarkus https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues/12469.
